awd_titl_txt: Transport and Distribution of Mitochondrial Copper
awd_abstract_narration:
Copper is an essential element required for aerobic life. This project addresses the fundamental eukaryotic cellular process of copper trafficking to mitochondria. Copper is required in mitochondria as part of an enzyme complex that is intrinsically linked to the production of energy for cells. However the mechanism of transport of copper to mitochondria and the trafficking within the organelle are not well understood. The identity of proteins and/or molecules involved in the delivery and distribution of copper is crucial to understanding the larger picture of regulation and coordinated assembly pathways. Baker's yeast, Saccharomyces cerevisiae, is used as a simple system to perform genetic and biochemical experiments to identify and understand the proteins and molecules involved in the homeostasis of copper in mitochondria. This project will define the mechanism of the copper transporter that facilitates movement across the otherwise impermeable inner membrane of mitochondria, identify alternative or complementary pathways of transport and characterize the molecule that binds copper to make it biologically available to mitochondria.

BROADER IMPACTS
The ease and safety of yeast experiments allows novice researchers to begin to address complex problems. Encompassed in this project is a teaching enhancement program for Alabama high schools. High school students spend two weeks in the laboratory learning experimental strategies that can be translated into their high school classroom. After working in the laboratory for two weeks the student demonstrates their proficiency by teaching their science teacher the experimental design and strategy they have learned. The design is then implemented into their high school science curriculum. This project also provides training for graduate and undergraduate students at Auburn University and will lead to a more complete understanding of an essential pathway for the larger scientific community.

por.por_cntn:
Copper is required for many cellular functions but the pathways for delivery of copper to certain targets are poorly understood. The cellular roles of copper include energy production, protection against oxygen induced damage and uptake of essential elements. However copper that is mishandled can cause cellular death. Therefore, understanding how copper is distributed is fundamental to life. 

In this project we have identified and characterized proteins required for transport of copper across the inner membrane of mitochondria. Once this copper is in the mitochondria it is used for synthesis of a critical copper enzyme cytochrome c oxidase and superoxide dismutase. An interesting and surprising result of this work is that copper enters mitochondria via transporters previously identified as phosphate and iron transporters. Therefore rather than a dedicated lock-and-key these transporters appear to be more promiscuous and adopt a lock-and-"best available key". We have studied this by combining genetics and biochemistry monitoring the changes in phenotypes under copper stress of yeast as a model and then physically testing the transport of copper with careful biochemical measurements in artificial membranes and the bacterium Lactococcus lactis.  These experiments broadened and advanced our knowledge of the cell biology of copper and added fundamental details to an important and poorly understood pathway.

Graduate students (~10) were trained in interdisciplinary science ranging from genetics to small molecule purification and biophysical characterization, basic scientific methods, scientific communication with peers and general public and development of mentoring skills by working with undergraduate students (>80) on one semester long research projects. In addition, the project was a vehicle for working with Alabama high school students in summer long projects (5 students), science fair projects (10 students) or as part of the Auburn University Summer Science Institute (30 students).
